Article.Abstract: Although the role of CD28-B7 interaction in the activation of naive T cells is well established, its importance in the generation and maintenance of T cell memory is not well understood. In this study, we examined the requirement for CD28-B7 interactions in primary T cell activation and immune memory. Ag-specific CD8 T cell responses were compared between wild-type (+/+) and CD28-deficient (CD28(-/-)) mice following an acute infection with lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV). During the primary response, there was a substantial activation and expansion of LCMV-specific CD8 T cells in both +/+ and CD28(-/-) mice. However, the magnitude of the primary CD8 T cell response to both dominant and subdominant LCMV CTL epitopes was approximately 2- to 3-fold lower in CD28(-/-) mice compared with +/+ mice; the lack of CD28-mediated costimulation did not lead to preferential suppression of CD8 T cell responses to the weaker subdominant epitopes. As seen in CD28(-/-) mice, blockade of B7-mediated costimulation by CTLA4-Ig treatment of +/+ mice also resulted in a 2-fold reduction in the anti-LCMV CD8 T cell responses. Loss of CD28/B7 interactions did not significantly affect the generation and maintenance of CD8 T cell memory; the magnitude of CD8 T cell memory was approximately 2-fold lower in CD28(-/-) mice as compared with +/+ mice. Further, in CD28(-/-) mice, LCMV-specific memory CD8 T cells showed normal homeostatic proliferation in vivo and also conferred protective immunity. Therefore, CD28 signaling is not necessary for the proliferative renewal and maintenance of memory CD8 T cells.
Article.ArticleTitle: Role of CD28-B7 interactions in generation and maintenance of CD8 T cell memory.
Article.Affiliations: Emory Vaccine Center and Department of Microbiology and Immunology, Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, GA 30322, USA.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Animals; Antigens, Viral(immunology); Arenaviridae Infections(immunology); B7-1 Antigen(metabolism; physiology); CD28 Antigens(genetics; metabolism; physiology); Cells, Cultured; Cytotoxicity Tests, Immunologic; Homeostasis; Immunodominant Epitopes(immunology); Immunologic Memory; Lymphocyte Activation; Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus(immunology); Mice; Mice, Inbred C57BL; Mice, Knockout; T-Lymphocytes, Cytotoxic(immunology)

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope specific cells were measured after LCMV infection of wild type and CD28 knockout mice. The same pattern of immunodominance was observed to LCMV epitopes in both strains with a lower number of epitope specific cells (2-3 fold) observed in the CD28-/- mice early after infection, although the maintenance of epitope specific memory cells was similar in both strains. Use of blocking anti-CTLA-4 antibody gave results similar to the CD28-/- mice. Prior LCMV infection was protective against LCMV in both wild type and CD28-/- mice.

The number of epitope specific memory cells (CD8+CD44hi) proliferating in CD28-/- mice was comparable to the wild type at 60 days after LCMV infection, demonstrating that the lack of the CD28/B7 interaction did not affect the response of epitope specific memory cells.

CD8+ T cells from wild type and CD28 knockout mice infected with LCMV produced similar levels of IFNg in response to the epitope. The same pattern of immunodominance was observed to LCMV epitopes in both strains with a lower number of epitope specific cells (2-3 fold) observed in the CD28-/- mice early after infection, although the maintenance of epitope specific memory cells was similar in both strains. The activation threshold of CD8+ T cells to LCMV epitopes was similar in both mice at day 60 post-infection, demonstrating that the lack of the CD28/B7 interaction did not affect the response of epitope specific memory cells.

The activation threshold of CD8+ T cells to LCMV epitopes was similar in both mice at day 60 post infection, demonstrating that the lack of the CD28/B7 interaction did not affect the response of epitope specific memory cells.
